title: Greil-Slawenlegende(origins of slavic nations)(1972)
description:
For english-only speaking:
This book is in german language. English title would be: The legend of Slavs - Germans as victims of faked history - Explanatory documentation (1972). History is often only a tool based on lies and fakeries in the hands of power politics that redirects the fate of the world according to its secret plans. If one today visits south and eastern Europe from a far-away land, he would immediately notice an incredible number of little nations that loosely describe themselves as slavic in origin but can barely understand eachother's language. But was it always like that? Where is the origin of this national schizophrenia? Lothar Greil goes back to history to uncover a startling origin of today's slavic nations and the political movement known as panslavism. In the times of communism it was politically correct to say that all these slavic people are immigrants from lands occupied by the former Soviet Union although a far more natural explanation should be obvious. As hinted by archeological excavations, many hundreds of years ago all these lands were occupied by a number of tribes that had no idea of what "Poles", "Czechs", "Slovaks", "Ukrainians", "Romanians", "Bulgars", "Slovenians", "Croatians", "Serbs" etc. mean. It is the physical historic record from excavations that tells a very different story of their actual origin. It seems that they were far more connected (if not identical) to the germanic tribes at the north than any other as indicated by their language and names of people and cities. As the author notices, something quite revolutionary had to have happened, that all these people "suddenly" started to speak in languages completely different from germanic dialects. It is interesting to note that this period also coincides with massive (and forceful) christianization of Europe as undertaken by the Church of Rome. Today we know that the strange writing known as "glagolica" was spread by catholic monks throughout of southern Balkans. Is it possible that this was just a small part in a larger plan of Roman catholic church to completely change the language, culture and national identity of germanic tribes throughout southern and eastern Europe? As the author concludes, this is exactly the case, resulting in unnatural language confusion and what is even more important - endless hatred against the Germans who refused to be christianized and later protested against Rome. In such a way a whole buffer of small now called "slavic" nations was created around central area of today's Germany that would throughout time feel completely alienated from their germanic roots. Greil convincigly demonstrates that simply all of names of people and cities throughout southern and eastern Europe evolved from their germanic roots and were later cleverly masked by the "slavic" counterparts. This rare and important documentation serves as a striking example of roman policy of "divide et empera" (divide/confuse and rule) that created the national madness that would result in incredible hatred and wars among the people that were once part of the same linguistic and racial group. 145 pages.
